sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to the ninth unit of our English learning journey. Today, we'll explore the Present Perfect Continuous tense, expressed as 'I have been doing'

sections.title: Definition
sections.content: This tense helps us convey the idea of actions that started in the past, have continued, and may still be ongoing. Let's delve into the key concepts.

sections.title: Formation
points: I have been studying for two hours

sections.title: Usage
sections.content: Describe actions that started in the past, have continued, and may still be happening.
points: She has been working at the company since last year.
Emphasize the ongoing nature or progress of an action.
They have been renovating their house for weeks

sections.title: Examples
sections.content: Let's examine examples to illustrate the application of the Present Perfect Continuous tense:

examples.Positive: We have been practicing the piano for hours.
examples.Negative: He has not been watching TV all day
examples.Interrogative: Have you been studying Spanish recently?

sections.title: Time Expression
sections.content: Introduce time expressions relevant to the Present Perfect Continuous tense.
points: For, since, all day, lately, recently

sections.title: Common Mistakes
sections.content: Address common mistakes related to the use of the present perfect continuous tense.
points: Incorrect:I have been knowing her for years
Correct: I have known her for years.

sections.title: Recap and Summary:
sections.content: In summary, the Present Perfect Continuous tense helps us convey the duration and ongoing nature of actions that started in the past. It emphasizes the process and may still be continuing.

sections.title: Additional Resources:
sections.content: For additional practice and reinforcement, consider exploring online exercises or referring to reliable grammar guides.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Thank you for joining today's lesson on the Present Perfect Continuous tense. Practice using it to describe ongoing activities in various contexts, and feel free to reach out if you have any questions. Happy learning!
